stream_context.summary: Kaze does bug/performance verification on real N64 hardware, then focuses on shaping and playtesting platforming for an icy castle level (Course 13). Midstream he live-reacts to F3 (fan game showcase) and shares thoughts on ROM hack creativity, marketing/preview strategy, and Nintendo C&D misconceptions. He closes by noting Course 13 is targeted for completion within ~a month, leaving two levels remaining.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete progress on Course 13 layout/platforming, real-hardware performance/AA testing notes, and several documentary-relevant statements about ROM hacks vs commercial games, preview/marketing strategy, legal/physical-release constraints, and post-baby work dynamics.

findings.summary: Kaze reports a week of concentrated bug fixing and "minuscule performance tweaks," saying he’s close to finishing his bug/performance to-do list. He demonstrates an in-game anti-aliasing toggle on real N64 hardware and checks framerate in a stress area (~45–46 FPS with AA on).
findings.quote: Over the last week or so, I did a lot of bug fixing here… minuscule performance tweaks… I almost finished my to-do list regarding bugs and performance issues.

findings.summary: A previously broken pipe/warp that "never worked on N64" now functions after a recent fix, but Kaze notices remaining timing issues (a timer running too fast) and speculates it may relate to PAL or uncapped FPS behavior.
findings.quote: There’s a pipe here that never worked on N64… It works! …The timer is going way too fast.

findings.summary: Kaze highlights a fast iteration loop for console testing: he can switch from emulator/dev view to real N64 output quickly via a button/capture setup. While testing, he observes a major camera issue and framebuffer artifacts, attributing camera instability to the level being too large and noting he may need to invent a solution (but defers it for now).
findings.quote: All I have to do to test this on the N64 is hit this button… Then I turn on my N64… I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this.

findings.summary: While playtesting the Course 13 intro (slide into a “snowman path”), Kaze identifies awkward wall-kick alignment and a jump that feels awkward even if not difficult. He adjusts the layout to be easier and brings geometry inward partly to avoid the camera problem triggered by huge areas.
findings.quote: These ones should probably be a little more parallel… the wall kicks are otherwise a bit awkward… Let's make it easier… and bring everything in a little bit so that the camera issue doesn't pop up.

findings.summary: Kaze states Course 13 is already well underway and he hopes to finish it within about a month; after that, only two levels would remain.
findings.quote: This is course 13… I hope I can finish this level in the next month or so and then it's just two levels missing.

findings.summary: On physical release: Kaze says he is not allowed to sell real cartridges. Instead, he plans to produce a souvenir box and booklet with no Nintendo references. He anticipates third parties may produce illegal cartridges, but he wants no involvement; he warns a “complete set” would likely be expensive through unofficial means.
findings.quote: I am not allowed to sell real cartridges… I’m planning to do… a box and a book inlet without any Nintendo references… I’m sure there will be illegally manufactured cartridges by other people.

findings.summary: Kaze explains why ROM hacks can feel more exciting than mainstream releases: commercial sequels must sell broadly and trend bland, while ROM hacks can take creative risks because they don't need mass-market approval.
findings.quote: ROM hacks don't have to sell well… so ROM hacks can get a little more creative.

findings.summary: He describes a deliberate communication strategy: viewers prefer technical videos and many avoid spoiler-heavy previews, but he still needs to show progress to prevent the audience from assuming development stalled. His solution is to “hide” level previews inside technical topics (e.g., using a new N64 feature as the video hook) as both marketing and proof of progress.
findings.quote: I have to hide [previews] under actual technical videos… otherwise people are going to be disgruntled.

findings.summary: Kaze pushes back on the recurring claim that showcases like F3 create a convenient takedown list for Nintendo. He argues that silence is self-sabotage (“you C&D'd yourself”), most projects won’t be targeted unless they become extremely popular, and anonymous release/leaks can still happen (citing the Mario 64 decomp leak history).
findings.quote: If you make a fan game and you shut up about it… you C&D'd yourself… You won't get C&D'd most likely unless your game gets really, really popular.

findings.summary: Kaze confirms his daughter was born five days earlier (named Reyna). He notes the workload of having a newborn is currently manageable because Zeina’s mom is helping, while acknowledging it’s probably still more work for Zeina than for him.
findings.quote: My child is named Reyna… Zeina's mom is helping us… it's probably a lot more work for Zeina than for me.

biobak.summary: Kaze credits Biobak with an enemy/NPC redesign idea (“fuzzies” reminiscent of Lost Impact) and says Biobak made the model; the new version includes protective gear.
biobak.quote: This was Biobak's idea and Biobak made the model. They're now wearing protective gear.

biobak.summary: Kaze indicates a plan/hope for Biobak to rework the level/area named "Koopa/Cooper Carnival" (unclear spelling in transcript).
biobak.quote: Is Biobak going to rework Cooper Carnival? I hope so. That is the plan anyway.

zeina.summary: Zeina is present in chat; Kaze mentions her mom is actively helping with childcare, and Kaze expects Zeina may appear on-stream again occasionally. He also acknowledges the newborn workload likely affects Zeina more.
zeina.quote: Zeina's mom is helping us… I'm sure Zeina is going to show up at least a few times again.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions switching to "Sauraen's profile," which changed various runtime/debug characteristics (including the FPS display position), implying a different performance/debug configuration or build profile is now in use.
findings.quote: It's because I switched to Sauraen's profile… Everything is a little different now.

findings.summary: ZeroVolt is present in chat, but no concrete new contribution is described in this transcript.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This is what the N64 games could have looked like. You were robbed.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while showing the hack running on real N64 with improved options like anti-aliasing and better performance—frames the project as a corrective reimagining of what the original hardware was capable of.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: ROM hacks don't have to sell well. So ROM hacks can get a little more creative.
memorable_quotes.context: Explains why fan projects can take design risks that commercial entries often avoid, aligning directly with the documentary’s core theme.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: You think about what feeling do I want to create… You don't want to operate on principles because if you operate on principles, you make art for critics.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze’s broader design philosophy: emotion/experience first, rules/principles second—useful for interviewing about art direction and level tone.

key_stories.title: Real-N64 iteration loop and the "big-area" camera problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates how quickly he can flip from dev workflow to real N64 testing (button/capture/N64 boot). In the same moment, testing reveals camera instability and framebuffer artifacts, which he links to oversized level bounds and deprioritizes until later.
key_stories.challenge: Ensuring Course 13 (and other levels) behave correctly on original hardware: stable camera, clean framebuffer, and acceptable performance.
key_stories.process: He repeatedly tests on N64 during development, uses FPS display/AA toggles, and diagnoses camera failure patterns (seemingly triggered by very large areas). He also adjusts geometry placement (bringing sections inward) to reduce triggering the camera issue.
key_stories.outcome: Short-term mitigation via level layout constraints; long-term need for a new technical solution for large-area camera behavior remains open.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this level is a little too big and that's why the camera does this… I might have to invent a solution to that problem.

key_stories.title: Packaging previews inside technical videos to show progress without spoiling
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains that straightforward level previews underperform because viewers prefer technical topics and avoid spoilers. To keep the audience confident the project is progressing, he intentionally frames previews as demonstrations of new N64/engine features.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining audience engagement and trust during a long development cycle while avoiding spoiler fatigue and low-performing preview content.
key_stories.process: He structures videos around technical hooks (e.g., render matrices, new engine features) and embeds level footage as proof of progress and application.
key_stories.outcome: A repeatable marketing/content strategy that both feeds the algorithm and documents progress, without relying on pure teasers.
key_stories.key_quote: Whenever I make a preview, it's like, 'Look how I used this new feature on the N64 to make this level.'

open_questions.topic: Course 13 identity, structure, and remaining work
open_questions.context: Kaze describes Course 13 as a surreal icy castle with a slide intro, a snowman-dodging path, interior rooms, and a planned large treasure room. He targets finishing the course within ~a month, leaving two courses remaining.
questions: What is Course 13’s final intended player fantasy and story context (why a treasure room, and what is the "surreal icy castle" supposed to evoke)?
What are the specific remaining tasks to call Course 13 "done" (stars, secrets, enemy placement, lighting, optimization, camera fixes, polish)?
Which two levels remain after Course 13, and are they larger/smaller in scope than Course 13?

open_questions.topic: PAL/uncapped-FPS timing bug affecting an in-level timer
open_questions.context: After fixing a pipe that previously failed on N64, Kaze observes a timer running too fast and wonders about PAL N64 behavior or unlimited FPS effects.
questions: What exactly caused the timer to run fast (frame-based logic, tick rate assumptions, PAL/NTSC timing differences, or uncapped FPS paths)?
How are time-based mechanics standardized across emulator, NTSC N64, and PAL N64 builds in Return to Yoshi’s Island?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions changing to Sauraen’s profile and notes that it altered behavior such as FPS display position and that "everything is a little different now."
questions: What is "Sauraen’s profile" concretely (a build config, toolchain changes, performance profiling preset, microcode/render pipeline settings)?
What measurable benefits did the switch provide (performance headroom, debugging clarity, compatibility, stability)?
Did it introduce any regressions or require re-tuning existing levels?

open_questions.topic: Large-area camera instability and planned technical solution
open_questions.context: Kaze attributes a major camera issue on real N64 to the level being too large and says he may need to invent a solution, but he is postponing it.
questions: What engine/camera limitation is being hit (coordinate precision, culling bounds, camera volume logic, memory/scene graph constraints)?
Is the long-term fix expected to be a code change (camera math/segmentation) or a design constraint (smaller rooms, more loading transitions)?
How will you validate the fix across all courses once implemented?

open_questions.topic: Physical "souvenir" release plan (box/booklet without Nintendo references)
open_questions.context: Kaze says he can’t sell cartridges, but wants to create physical packaging without Nintendo references so fans can own a keepsake; he expects third parties may make illegal carts.
questions: What will the box/booklet contain (original lore, art, making-of notes, level maps, credits), and who is creating the art/layout?
What legal guidance or lines are you using to decide what counts as a Nintendo reference (logos, character names, screenshots)?
Would you consider partnering with an independent printer/fulfillment service, and how would you handle international shipping/taxes?
